awd_titl_txt: II-NEW: GreenIT: Testbeds for Real-time Data Center and Platform Energy and Thermal Management
awd_abstract_narration:
GreenIT: Testbeds for Real-time Data Center and Platform Energy and Thermal Management - CRI Proposal 0958514
The projected power demand for data centers and servers in the US is expected to grow to about 100B kWh by 2011, and even expected efficiency improvements projected by the EPA are insufficient to cap steady growth in IT energy demand. In order to reign in this growth, the 'GreenIT' cross-cutting and cross-disciplinary project seeks solutions that span multiple disciplines (mechanical, civil, electrical, and computer science) and multiple technologies (chips/packaging, operating systems/software, cooling technologies and thermal/fluid modeling, at multiple length and time scales). The project approach is measurement-based, establishing a 'GreenIT' testbed for energy efficient IT. The testbed will operate at `data center scale', because it is coupled with ongoing efforts at Georgia Tech that are providing us both with (1) a large-scale, commodity IT infrastructure, i.e., racks of machines and (2) new facilities used for a multi-site collaboration in cloud computing. Commodity equipment and instrumentation are housed in the CEETHERM lab, in Mechanical Engineering at Georgia Tech, which offers dynamically controllable air cooling capabilities. This permits joint control of cooling and IT power consumption. Additional researcher-accessible measurement stations target new facilities and next generation multicore platforms.
A common thread in this research is its use and promotion of coordinated management 'across the energy stack', where management actions taken at different levels of the energy stack are performed in a coordinated manner. The outcome is holistic data center management for improved power efficiency.

por.por_cntn:
The funding provided for this project was used for establishing testbeds to support real-time datacenter and platform-level energy and thermal monitoring and management, in order to facilitate several research efforts concerning energy efficiency for datacenter and server systems conducted by researchers across the Schools of Computer Science, Electrical and Computer Engineering and Mechanical Engineering at Georgia Tech. 

For data center systems, an important characteristic of power consumption is that it is not just up to an individual branch of the IT industry to reign in the growth in energy demand. Instead, solutions must span multiple disciplines (mechanical, civil, electrical, and computer science) and multiple technologies (power distribution, chips/packaging, operating systems/software, cooling technologies and thermal/fluid modeling at multiple length and time scales). To address this challenge, this project acquired new equipment to construct a shared testbed as a foundation for a multi-disciplinary long term ‘GreenIT’ research program in energy efficient IT infrastructure. 

Key outcomes of the activities conducted under this award were (1.) the creation of a fully instrumented datacenter prototype facility, with sensors capturing temperature and power usage, as well as properties of the workloads (e.g., CPU and memory usage) and of the cooling systems (e.g., fans and HVAC), (2.) a scalable monitoring infrastructure to continuously aggregate, store, and analyze the instrumentation outputs, and (3.) a shared PowerLab with advanced equipment for platform- and component-level power and temperature measurement, needed to capture the behaviors of emerging complex multicore server systems. These resources enabled (4.) collaborative, cross-cutting research, the outcomes of which are disseminated via more than 30 publications, presentations at international conferences, datacenter operators events organized by different consortia, as well as to key technology companies and national labs. 

Intellectual merits include significant results from the research activities made possible with this funding, which provide insights and developed solutions regarding a range of problems across the entire stack – from chip- and board-level, up to scales that consider entire datacenter installations – including (i) the design of future datacenter cooling and air flow systems, (ii) improved methods for managing and mapping workloads on datacenter nodes or (iii) across cores in future, potentially heterogeneous, multicore platforms, in a manner that improves the energy-efficiency of individual nodes and the datacenter as a whole, (iv) understanding and managing the energy-related behavior of large-scale enterprise, cloud, and scientific workloads, and (v) platform- and circuit-level methods for power distribution and multiplexing that address thermal challenges on multi- and manycore nodes. 

Broader impacts from this work include significant outreach activities to disseminate research results, as well as insights regarding the value of the instrumented facility, to technology companies and datacenter industry alliances, as well as institutionally, to the Georgia Tech IT organization, which is currently planning the construction of a new datacenter facility to serve the broader regional community. Broader impacts are also achieved through education and training, via several PhD thesis, MS projects, and numerous special problems carried out in the context of these testbeds. All of these students are currently working on related problems in industry, including Intel, Google, VMware, NEC Labs, and many others.
